channel.title: Author Interviews : NPR
channel.description: NPR interviews with top authors and the NPR Book Tour, a weekly feature and podcast where leading authors read and discuss their writing. Subscribe to the RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Cartoonist Daniel Clowes On Time Travel And Giving Readers Their Money's Worth
item.description: At 55, Clowes is one of the most influential artists in the independent comics world. His latest book, Patience, uses time travel to look at the ways random events can set a life on a new path.
item.content:encoded: At 55, Clowes is one of the most influential artists in the independent comics world. His latest book, Patience, uses time travel to look at the ways random events can set a life on a new path.

item.title: After Tragedy, 2 Families Find Their Own Justice In Louise Erdrich's 'LaRose'
item.description: When an Ojibwe hunter accidentally kills his friend's child, he sends his own son to live with the grieving family. Erdrich says tribal family ties are "extremely close" and "much more fluid."
item.content:encoded: When an Ojibwe hunter accidentally kills his friend's child, he sends his own son to live with the grieving family. Erdrich says tribal family ties are "extremely close" and "much more fluid."
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: 'There Was More I Wanted To Say': Kate Tempest Turns Hit Album Into A Novel
item.description: The rapper's debut album, Everybody Down, followed Becky and Harry, two Londoners struggling with love, work and drugs. Now her new book, The Bricks That Built The Houses, takes a look at their pasts.
item.content:encoded: The rapper's debut album, Everybody Down, followed Becky and Harry, two Londoners struggling with love, work and drugs. Now her new book, The Bricks That Built The Houses, takes a look at their pasts.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Friend Or Fiend? 'Pit Bull' Explores The History Of America's Most Feared Dog
item.description: Author Bronwen Dickey says the idea of pit bulls as predators is based on myth and misinformation. In the early Hollywood era, Dickey says, the dogs were often chosen to appear in comedies.
item.content:encoded: Author Bronwen Dickey says the idea of pit bulls as predators is based on myth and misinformation. In the early Hollywood era, Dickey says, the dogs were often chosen to appear in comedies.

item.title: Richard Russo Returns To North Bath, NY, In 'Everybody's Fool'
item.description: The Pulitzer-Prize winning author of Empire Falls says his characters are inspired by his parents' working-class World War II generation. Russo's new novel is set in a small town in upstate New York.
item.content:encoded: The Pulitzer-Prize winning author of Empire Falls says his characters are inspired by his parents' working-class World War II generation. Russo's new novel is set in a small town in upstate New York.

item.title: 'Eleven Hours' Follows Two Soon-To-Be Moms In The Course Of One Labor
item.description: Pamela Erens' new book tells the story of a woman in labor and the nurse who helps her through it.
item.content:encoded: Pamela Erens' new book tells the story of a woman in labor and the nurse who helps her through it.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Chris Cleve's WWII Novel Draws From Family's Bravery
item.description: NPR's Lynn Neary asks Chris Cleve about his new novel Everyone Brave If Forgiven. He wanted to write about Randolph Churchill's World War II experiences but discovered surprising inspiration.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Lynn Neary asks Chris Cleve about his new novel Everyone Brave If Forgiven. He wanted to write about Randolph Churchill's World War II experiences but discovered surprising inspiration.

item.title: 'Little Mosque' Creator Zarqa Nawaz On Mixing Comedy And Religion
item.description: The writer/filmmaker uses humor to help people understand Islam, but it took years for some mosque members to come around to her jokes. Nawaz's new memoir is called Laughing All The Way to the Mosque.
item.content:encoded: The writer/filmmaker uses humor to help people understand Islam, but it took years for some mosque members to come around to her jokes. Nawaz's new memoir is called Laughing All The Way to the Mosque.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: After 20 Years On The Job, NYC Police Officer Tells His Intense Stories
item.description: "Your heart is pounding; your adrenaline is shooting out of your ears," retired police officer Steve Osborne says. "And you got one second to get it right." Originally broadcast April 21, 2015.
item.content:encoded: "Your heart is pounding; your adrenaline is shooting out of your ears," retired police officer Steve Osborne says. "And you got one second to get it right." Originally broadcast April 21, 2015.

item.title: Churchill Downer: The Forgotten Racial History Of Kentucky's State Song
item.description: "My Old Kentucky Home" is sung every year at the Kentucky Derby. Written in 1852 as an anti-slavery ballad, the song has a more sinister meaning upon closer examination.
item.content:encoded: "My Old Kentucky Home" is sung every year at the Kentucky Derby. Written in 1852 as an anti-slavery ballad, the song has a more sinister meaning upon closer examination.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: How Mexican Cuisine Was Doing Fusion 500 Years Ago
item.description: In her new cookbook, Mexican chef Pati Jinich explores the many cultures — from Africans to Chinese to French to Lebanese and more — who left their culinary imprint on her native country's cuisine.
item.content:encoded: In her new cookbook, Mexican chef Pati Jinich explores the many cultures — from Africans to Chinese to French to Lebanese and more — who left their culinary imprint on her native country's cuisine.
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: Newly Released Documents Detail Traumas Of China's Cultural Revolution
item.description: Historian Frank Dikötter says newly opened archives offer fresh details about the chaos China experienced in the 1960s, when Chairman Mao urged students to take to the streets.
item.content:encoded: Historian Frank Dikötter says newly opened archives offer fresh details about the chaos China experienced in the 1960s, when Chairman Mao urged students to take to the streets.

item.title: Novelist Richard Russo: 'I Find Myself Now ... Having Lived The American Dream'
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author says his blue-collar grandfather would have been astonished by the life Russo leads. His new book, Everybody's Fool, is a sequel to 1993's Nobody's Fool.
item.content:encoded: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author says his blue-collar grandfather would have been astonished by the life Russo leads. His new book, Everybody's Fool, is a sequel to 1993's Nobody's Fool.
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: 'Heat & Light' Digs For The Soul Of Coal Country
item.description: Jennifer Haigh grew up in small town Pennsylvania, where jobs disappeared when coal mines closed. Her new novel explores the changes that mining — and now fracking — has brought to nearby communities.
item.content:encoded: Jennifer Haigh grew up in small town Pennsylvania, where jobs disappeared when coal mines closed. Her new novel explores the changes that mining — and now fracking — has brought to nearby communities.
item.dc:creator: Lynn Neary

item.title: To Play Sports Under Taliban Rule, 'Different Kind Of Daughter' Dressed As A Boy
item.description: Growing up in the tribal region of Pakistan, Maria Toorpakai pretended she was a boy in order to compete as a weightlifter. Later she became an internationally known squash player.
item.content:encoded: Growing up in the tribal region of Pakistan, Maria Toorpakai pretended she was a boy in order to compete as a weightlifter. Later she became an internationally known squash player.
